title: The four most coveted watch brands
text:
Bani McSpedden Watch Editor Aug 29, 2019 — 12.00am Share

Watch lovers are a timid lot. The most fashionable wristwear right now has little to do with styles or complications, but everything to do with brand power. Despite the fact there are hundreds of brands manufacturing timepieces with incredible levels of accuracy and finishing, just four dominate today’s desirability rankings: Rolex, Patek Philippe, Audemars Piguet and Richard Mille.

Don’t merely take my word for it – every retailer and collector I speak to is at one on this assessment, with “unobtainium” surfacing as the word to describe the most popular watches from the above brands. So popular, you can barely buy one unless you’re prepared to wait, wait, wait or pay a pretty premium over the list price on the secondary market.

Watches falling into this category include any sports Rolex, AP’s Royal Oak and Offshore models, Patek’s Nautilus and Aquanaut offerings, and any item carrying Richard Mille’s upper-case logo. Meaning the most fashionable watches of the day are those you can’t get.

Erik Madigan Heck Trunk Archive / Snapper images

This doesn’t quite mean they’re barely in evidence. Rolex, for one, is selling more watches than any brand, period. It's just that Chinese appetite and trader-mania mean the watches never make it into Rolex boutique windows. Audemars Piguet recently changed its model to sell only through its own boutiques after so few of its timepieces became available to official AP retailers.

Richard Mille is so sure of selling everything it constructs that, like AP, it has pulled out of exhibiting at watch fairs and withdrawn from selling in Australia altogether. As such, window shopping has been replaced by wrist envy.

Rather than despair, this is in fact fabulous news for watch lovers. While the chosen brands finesse things to incredible degrees and concentrate on filling orders, those facing more of a struggle to maintain market share have had to lift their creative game. And this means greater choice when it comes to putting something less predictable on your wrist.

It is happening across all price points, as a glance at the latest catalogues show: Seiko and Oris have their dancing shoes on, while high-end brands H. Moser & Cie and Jaquet Droz are emerging as belles of the ball.

Droz was a stand-out at the Swatch Group’s 2019 product reveal for its top marques in Switzerland. The world’s watch press was in consensus about that, even when measured against competition like Breguet, Blancpain and Omega. Buying a Jaquet Droz will require the small effort of a trip to Melbourne if you’re not domiciled there, given the brand has no other outlets in Australia, but the reward of something distinctive awaits. A disproportionally large seconds hand is the brand’s schtick, and this surprisingly elegant feature distinguishes a range of models – from three-handers, chronographs and dual timers to exotic creations such as a miniature enamelled chiming bird repeater.

Jaquet Droz Grande Seconde Skelete soldier is for those that love all things mechanical. Supplied

But if you simply love all things mechanical it’s the Grande Seconde Skelet-One Ceramic you’ll want on your wrist, it being the kind of watch that holds your attention whether you’re looking for the time or simply looking to pass it. As for credentials – its looks are enough to win admiring glances – they’re impeccable. The 41.5mm case is in black ceramic, the exposed, black-coated self-winding movement has a white-gold oscillating weight that powers up two barrels with 68 hours in reserve, there’s a fancy silicon balance spring and – well, just look at it.

Does that mean you can forget about that Rolex Submariner or GMT-Master? Not quite. You’re not going to wear the Jaquet Droz every day – it’s more like a McLaren compared with a Mercedes-AMG. Meaning the best bet might be to order the Rolex, but buy the Droz to take your mind off the wait.

description: Waiting lists for the more popular timepieces are long, so you need to know what to wear in the meantime.
